course.subject: SOSC
course.name: Population and Development in China
course.description: This course will first introduce formal demography and population studies as two major parts of demography and then investigate details about measurements about, major patterns of, and explanations to population size, growth, distribution, composition as well as three demographic processes fertility, mortality and migration.

reviews.author: Kabul
reviews.title: Easy course and very light workload
reviews.comment_content:
Introductory demographic analysis. Includes some theoretical models to explain the population phenomenon in the world, particularly China, for example, the consideration of implementing one-child policy in China, and why fertility rate is lower in developed countries than in developing countries.

Probably not very practical but still interesting to know.

1️⃣ Population Growth
2️⃣ Population Distribution
3️⃣ Migration
4️⃣ Population by Age and Sex
5️⃣ Mortality
6️⃣ Fertility

除咗部分 economic analysis, e.g. utility analysis of fertility 之外，其他都係簡單嘢。

reviews.author: Ccystance
reviews.title: For those who can stay focused in a 3-hour class + interested in demography and population, particularly of China's
reviews.comment_content:
1. Population Growth and Economic Development: Causes, Consequences, and Controversies
2. Population Composition by Age and Sex: Marriage Squeeze and Population Aging
3. Fertility Analysis: Trends, Levels and Explanations
4. Migration: Explanation and Evaluation of Its Impact
5. Mortality Analysis: Causes, Epidemiological Transition, and Differentials in Mortality
6. Population Distribution: Urban and Regional Growth (optional)  (Do not have enough time to cover)　

** There are no class recordings (not until the last week of final exam)
reviews.comment_teaching:
His voice is a bit boring. Since the class lasts for 3 hours (usually the last half hour will be video playing), it is not easy to stay focused. Be prepared there are a lot of points that is not on his lecture notes (it is pretty brief but there are main ideas and concepts) so you would like to try to take as many notes as possible, especially when he said it is important and will be tested. There are a lot of numbers/ figures in his notes and he would explain the meaning behind, be sure to mark them down. Similar to figures, it is suggested to remember the context behind the graphs/ trends.

Other than that, he is knowledgeable and familiar with this field. I learned quite a lot about contemporary population and demography trends in different countries as well as China's historical migration, population changes. I would say is an insightful course.

He is also friendly and good at explaining so feel free to ask him during class. If you have questions regarding HW/ quiz, find TA Ms.Ying Deng, highly responsive and helpful.

Please note he would use an amount of Mandarin on class and some topics require background knowledge about China's development, internationals may need to do some additional readings to better understand the content.
reviews.comment_grading:
The content is not that hard, but since it has no mid-term and all content will be tested in the close-book final exam, you would need to spend more time on memorization. I spent around 5 days before exam to memorize and make a simple note.

I got above average and higher for two assignments, unknown results for final, attendance and quiz 100%, A- at last.
reviews.comment_workload:
2 assignments (do it earlier since it takes some time to calculate, it is not a simple one but it is not too challenging)
1 final exam
some very easy quizzes to count your participation

reviews.author: dying
reviews.title: Moderately easy course
reviews.comment_content:
This course is mainly about the modern population development of China from around the 1950s till the present. There are some calculations such as population and fertility rate, which you have to memorize the theories and formulas in the final exam.  

Course Structure

1. Population Growth and Economic Development: Causes, Consequences, and Controversies
2. Population Composition by Age and Sex: Marriage Squeeze and Population Aging
3. Fertility Analysis: Trends, Levels and Explanations
4. Migration: Explanation and Evaluation of Its Impact
5. Mortality Analysis: Causes, Epidemiological Transition, and Differentials in Mortality
6. Population Distribution: Urban and Regional Growth (optional)
reviews.comment_teaching: The course is a 3-hour lecture every week. The professor was good at explaining the facts and sometimes would tell us about his past in China. But I often dozed off during his lectures, as his voice sounds like he is mumbling. He sometimes also uses mandarin and Chinese characters to explain some terminology, so non-local students have to bear this in mind.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignment (2)         22%
Class attendance & Quizs  (5)     15%
Final Exam (MC, Calculation, essay Qs) 60%
Discussion (answering professor's questions or asking him questions during breaks)               3%

The assignments are not hard as most of the answers can be found in the slide, but you have elaborate on them and do multiple calculations. Most importantly, the grade heavily depends on the final exam.

I got A- for my final grade. Both of my assignments are above the mean by 4 to 5 marks. The mark for final exam was unreleased.
reviews.comment_workload: There are 2 assignments and in-class quizzes about the videos which the TA plays. So be sure to attend classes as the in-class quizzes are randomly released after the professor's lecture.

reviews.comment_teaching:
John is really nice, willing to answer questions in the chat room & he will share many interesting stories during class. He will also repeat the main concepts (mainly for SQs) many times & revise with us during the next lecture, so you can get them clear.
However, non-Chinese speakers will be confused as Putonghua will be sometimes used for explaining specific terms/policies in China.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grade!!!
Quizzes: easy
Assignments: average
Final exam: easy SQ (just like answering DSE Econ Qs), difficult MC, average calculations
reviews.comment_workload:
Average workload.
Quizzes are random quizzes based on the videos played at the end of the class & 3 easy questions/ Quiz, Reading materials are supplementary, but the final needs more time as the ppt is a little bit clumsy and you have no idea what will he asked in the MC, so I try to remember all things when I revised...

reviews.author: Yat
reviews.title: Just don't take this course, OK?
reviews.comment_content:
Course Structure
1. Population Growth and Economic Development: Causes, Consequences, and Controversies
2. Fertility Analysis: Trends, Levels and Explanations
3. Population Composition by Age and Sex: Marriage Squeeze and Population Aging
4. Migration: Explanation and Evaluation of Its Impact
5. Population Distribution: Urban and Regional Growth
6. Mortality Analysis: Causes, Epidemiological Transition, and Differentials in Mortality
Special Sessions: GIS mapping of population (TBA)

Basically, it is all presented in the 6 lecture notes.
reviews.comment_teaching:
What he does essentially, is go through every slide with some explanations, mixed with some Chinese old phrases and personal stories (sometimes with projector help).

The teaching is fine, since he would illustrate economic models by hand-drawing; but how could that be acceptable considering the bad content?

At the end of the lecture, documentary about some China issues would be played, One Child, Sex ratio, Marriage; but you could actually look it up on youtube.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assessment: Assignment (2) 15%
Mid-term exam (MC & Short Qs) 25%
Class attendance & Quizs (5) 15%
Final Exam (MC & Short Qs) 45%

Q1:3/3
Q2:2/3
Q3:3/4
Questions were asked throughout the whole video, so beware of some tricky questions.

Assignment 1: 91/100
Mid-term: Not given
Final: Not given

Assignment 1 is the only assignment and it is rather easy calculation, so... no problem.
Final was actually conducted online, where there were MCQs and 1 essay question about Population/ Economic model.

Grade: B-
The grade is actually bad, since there are no reasons that I don't even get a B, given that I at least revised and had basic understanding of the whole content, stupid course.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not much workload, nor not much you could really study about, unless you are determined to recite every single thing in the lecture notes.

The whole content was just things you would not care about, population and economic in China, with the comparison to other countries (Japan, US, Brazil, India); and the actual history of certain policy in the past, which would be tested in the exam.

There was no attendance actually, but the quizzes were conducted at the end of lecture with no prior notice.

I recommend you to drop the course, after have a glimpse of it, it doesn't worth your time given the bad grade, bad content.

The outline of the course:
1. Population Growth and Economic Development: Causes, Consequences, and Controversies
2. Fertility Analysis: Trends, Levels and Explanations
3. Population Composition by Age and Sex: Marriage Squeeze and Population Aging

There are two suggested textbooks but I don't recommend you to read them. Just stick to the lecture notes and pay attention to the professor's speech in lectures.

Not difficult to understand. I would say the course is a little bit advanced LS course in modern China plus some theories needed to remember and apply.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is warm-hearted and he tries to teach the best to students. However, the tone and accent are very bad. He spoke too slow and boring. Sometimes he uses mandarin to explain some terms and concepts.

Jotting notes is better than you read the textbook alone!!!
Bring coffee when you attend the lecture because his tone will make you sleep!!!
reviews.comment_grading:
Before the final exam, my score is above 0.269 sd. After the final exam, I got an A.

No release for the marks for both midterm and final exams. I just knew the equivalent percentage of the current total grade before the final exam. Not transparent.
reviews.comment_workload:
This semester is special. Due to the suspension of classes, he canceled the second assignment and the upcoming quizzes, so the percentage of final increases from 45% to 60%.

The first assignment is easy, just some high school maths. Just be careful about which formula has to be used.

I suggest you attend all the lectures because it has pop-up quizzes, but the quizzes are at the end of the lecture. Quizzes are not related to the lecture notes, the questions are based on the video played by the TA, easy questions and almost everyone got full mark. Not need to revise for the quizzes.

The midterm is around 20MCs, one short essay question. The final is open book only for this semester. Similar to midterm, Mcs and one short essay question. I think the difficulty for the final is lower than the previous regular semester, just for this semester.

He provided lecture videos (but I think just for this semester because those videos only covered materials after suspension of classes). I watched them all before the final exams, 6 hours in total, extra 2 hours to revise, then A range.

reviews.author: Angez
reviews.title: 背多分，背背佳
reviews.comment_content:
This course aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of population growth, distribution, composition, major demographic processes and their relationship with economic development. Special attention is given to the demographic trends and policies in both the Chinese Mainland and Hong Kong SAR. Basic concepts of economics and knowledge of development in the region are required for the exams. Students are assessed according to their performance in the final exam, assignments, random quizs and class discussion.

Course Structure
1. Population Growth and Economic Development: Causes, Consequences, and Controversies
2. Population Composition by Age and Sex: Marriage Squeeze and Population Aging
3. Fertility Analysis: Trends, Levels and Explanations
4. Migration: Explanation and Evaluation of Its Impact
5. Mortality Analysis: Causes, Epidemiological Transition, and Differentials in Mortality
6. Population Distribution: Urban and Regional Growth (optional)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Ma teaches very well and often says "OK". He is a very kind teacher, and the TAs are also competent.
This semester, we have online classes on Zoom, and Professor Ma is very active in answering student questions. The class lasts a long time, but there are breaks in between.

He does not speak Mandarin very often during class and usually repeats what he says in English, so there is no problem for non-Mandarin speakers to attend the class. As long as you can memorize the PPTs (which are in English), you can even get a good grade without understanding what is being taught in class. There are no recordings to watch, but there are recordings(audio) to listen to.

====================================

马老师教得挺好的，经常说OK。很和善的老师，TA也称职。
我们这学期是zoom上课，马老师回答学生问题很积极。一整节课上下来时间很长，但是中间会给休息的时间。
上课说得普通话其实不多，而且都又讲了一遍英文。不存在说听不懂中文就上不了课的程度。
没有recording看，但是有录音可以听。
reviews.comment_grading:
Assessment: Assignment (2) 22%
Class attendance & Quizs (5) 15%
Final Exam (MC, Calculation, essay Qs) 60%
Discussion 3%

Mine:
Assignment 1 100/100
Assignment 2 84/100
Quiz(×3) 15/15
Final (Calculation, MC, Short Essay) don't know the mark ?/100

I got A+.
I think except the Assignment 2 and the final, I got full marks on everything.
The final is quite easy I would say, if you are well-prepared.
reviews.comment_workload:
The course is still quite relaxed. Class participation is required through class discussions, and during the Zoom period, the number of times a student speaks is counted, so just repeat the answers along with other classmates.
The quizzes are multiple-choice questions based on the videos shown in class. If you listen carefully, you will be able to answer them.
The two assignments consist of calculation questions and short answer questions, and you need to use Word to create statistical charts, which are similar to the problem sets in the Business School (I am from the School of Engineering).

During the last class, Professor Ma will discuss the exam points for the final exam, so it is important to take notes and review them.
However, I memorized all of the lecture notes, including the various charts and data, and did well on the final exam. Therefore, memorizing more will earn you more points, and if you memorize enough, you will get a good grade.

In my personal opinion, the content of the lecture notes was covered in the final exam, and the short essay questions were quite objective. Simply reiterating the theoretical content from the PPT is enough, and there is no need to write a lot of your own thoughts.

I did not feel that there was any fierce competition with students from SHSS, it's not that hard :)

====================================

还是很轻松的，上课需要参与课堂讨论，zoom时期就是统计发言次数，跟着其他同学一起复读答案就可以。

Quiz是单选题，上课看视频，回答几个视频中提到答案的问题，基本上听了就会做。

两个assignment都是计算题和简答题，需要拿word做统计图，和商院那些problem set有点像（我本人是工院的）。

最后一节课马老师会讲期末考试的考点，都记下来复习就行。

但我背下了所有的lecture notes，包括里面的各种图表和数据，期末考试直接嘎嘎乱杀。所以背多分、背背佳，背了分就多，背了成绩就好。

我个人感觉期末考试lecture notes上的内容都被考到了，Short Essay问题其实挺客观的，复述一下PPT里讲得理论就行，不需要写很多自己的想法。

也没觉得有什么文院大佬竞争内卷难，或者说他们也没能竞争过我:)

MCs----40 mins (30 questions)
5-min Break
Short Essay ----- 75 mins  (two questions)

reviews.comment_workload:
Very light workload with only some easy quizs and assignments. Final was easier than expected just MCs were tricky, requiring students to be very familiar with every points or data as those options. Final essay questions were just memorizing and applying those theories is ok to deal with.
As the topic is related to society, I don't think we need to memorize much things, using common sense to understand the materials is enough.
Overall it is not a hard course to study, I didn't study during the semester, pay attention on class and understand every points is enough. Final was like memorizing and reviewing. The most satisfying course ever !!!
